ghostPage.title: S/S Christian Radich
ghostPage.excerpt: Christian Radich was built in clinched steel, with a call sign of LJLM, home port in Oslo, and an IMO number of 5071729.

ghostPage.plaintext:
The S/S Christian Radich, a Norwegian full-rigged ship, has sailed through decades of maritime history. Its exceptional design, thrilling regatta records, and ongoing role in seafaring education and adventure have cemented its place in maritime lore.

Masterful Construction

The S/S Christian Radich was crafted by Framnæs Mekaniske Verksted in Sandefjord, Norway, in 1937. The ship boasts impressive dimensions, measuring 62.5 meters in total length or 73 meters inclusive of the bowsprit. Its width spans 9.7 meters, with a depth of 4.7 meters, and a striking height above the waterline of 37.7 meters, making it both an imposing and gracefully balanced vessel.

Outfitted with an extensive sail area of 1360 square meters, the ship incorporates 15 square sails, 11 staysails, and a mizzen sail. This powerful arrangement enables the Christian Radich to achieve speeds of up to 14 knots under full sail.

Additionally, the ship houses a 900 horsepower Caterpillar engine, allowing it to maintain a speed of up to 10 knots under power.

Life Onboard

The ship is well-equipped to accommodate its crew. It offers positions for a captain, 2-3 navigators, a boatswain, a carpenter, 4 sailors, 1-2 engineers, a steward, and 1-2 cooks. Notably, the ship also includes a position for a sergeant, a role somewhat unique for a civilian sailing vessel.

History and Use

The Christian Radich owes its name to the Norwegian shipowner who financed a substantial part of the construction. Initially, the ship served as a training vessel for young sailors. It later made a name for itself in the film and television industry, with appearances in the 1958 film "Windjammer" and the 1970s BBC series "The Onedin Line."

Today, the ship is owned by the Stiftelsen Skoleskipet Christian Radich Foundation and is based in Oslo. From 2005 to 2015, it served as a training ship for the Norwegian Navy.

Regatta Glory

The Christian Radich boasts a distinguished record in the regatta circuit. It has achieved top placements in numerous races over the years, including multiple wins of the esteemed Cape Horn Trophy. Among its notable victories are the 2011 Waterford – Greenock race and the 2009 Gdynia – St. Petersburg race.

Legacy and Purpose

The S/S Christian Radich continues to play an essential role in preserving Norway's maritime heritage. As a symbol of seafaring adventure and a tangible link to Norway's nautical past, it remains an ambassador of Norwegian maritime tradition, participating in international maritime events and providing sail training opportunities.

By embodying the perfect mix of history, craftsmanship, and adventure, the S/S Christian Radich is more than just a ship — it's a living piece of Norwegian maritime history.
